;当 Hanoch Hai Cohen 走进以色列南部 Re'im 基布兹附近的森林空地时周六黎明，数千名年轻人已经在夜空下跳舞或在附近的帐篷里露营。这个名为 Nova 的音乐节非常热闹，以至于 31 岁、住在特拉维夫的科恩在听到火箭的声音之前就看到了火箭。几名警察很快赶到并驱散了聚会，高喊着“红色”——在以色列，火箭弹袭击的代号。

;

;当参加聚会的人争先恐后地走向自己的汽车或躺在地上等待炮火袭击时过去，另一种火灾开始了。科恩看到四辆载满武装武装分子和骑摩托车的枪手的皮卡车包围了通往活动场地的道路，该道路上挤满了试图逃离该地区的汽车。 “他们向一米外的人开枪，”科恩周日在电话中告诉我。 “这些都是处决。我们就像靶场里的鸭子一样。”

;

;音乐节是史无前例的;哈马斯地面入侵;以色列。这或许也是最致命的。据以色列搜救组织称，那里至少有 260 人被杀。

;

;武装分子还袭击了附近的社区，挨家挨户地杀害和带走居民，在某些情况下，甚至整群人都被杀害。家庭—;

;周日下午，在以色列，随着电台播音员继续宣读遇难者的名字，人们开始了解灾难的严重程度。一些故事有美好的结局：餐厅在贝埃里基布兹，大约有 50 名居民被扣为人质，;被解放了;； ;英雄父亲;他从特拉维夫乘车出发，在以色列士兵的帮助下，称他击毙了进入他儿子位于纳哈尔奥兹基布兹家中的恐怖分子，拯救了他的儿子和儿媳以及他们的两个年幼的孩子。挤在一个加固的房间里面。但恐怖视频在 Telegram 等社交媒体平台上流传，其中一些视频似乎来自哈马斯运营的账户。这些媒体有时会向疯狂的亲属提供有关其亲人的唯一新闻，其中一些包含错误信息。

;
;
;

;周六，摩西·奥尔 (Moshe Or) 在大规模征兵期间南下参加预备役服役，一名熟人给他发短信说，一段有关摩西弟弟的视频正在流传。莫谢点开视频，看到自己三十岁的弟弟阿维纳坦被一群武装分子包围并背着双手带走。阿维纳坦的女友诺亚·阿加玛尼 (Noa Argamani) 尖叫着被另一伙武装分子骑着摩托车带走。

;

;“天塌下来了，”摩西周六晚上在电话中告诉我。他知道阿维纳坦和诺亚参加了新星节。 “但你的内心充满了虚假的希望，”他说。 “你一直说，他的电池没电了，或者他可能逃进了森林。然后你就会看到最糟糕的事情：你的小弟弟被恐怖分子带走了。”从那时起，摩西就没有收到任何有关他兄弟的消息，也没有从任何官员那里听到有关绑架的消息。他说，他和阿维纳坦一样，曾在军队的一个战斗部队服役。 “我们为国家服务，为国家服务。但现在的感觉是，这个国家并不关心我们。”

;

;周六晚些时候，我还与阿加马尼最亲密的儿时好友什洛米特·马西亚诺 (Shlomit Marciano) 通了电话。她坐在阿伽玛尼父母位于中南部城市贝尔谢巴的家里。她正在谈论她的朋友“拥有一颗伟大的心”，她下周将满二十六岁，当时我听到一个男人在背景中哭泣：“上帝帮助我，上帝帮助我。”

;

;马西亚诺向他道歉我，并解释说这是阿伽玛尼的父亲雅科夫。她说，他刚刚重看了女儿被带入加沙的视频。

;

;周日，雅科夫对记者发表了讲话。 “战争够了，我们所看到的一切也够了，”他用微弱的声音恳求道。然后他向对方详细说明了费用。 “他们也在战争中失去了亲人。他们还有俘虏。他们也有哀悼的母亲。让我们投入我们的情感。我们是同一个父亲出身的两个国家。 。 。请让我们和平相处吧。真正的和平，”他声音沙哑地说。 ♦

;周六，哈马斯武装分子从加沙地带攻入以色列，造成数百人死亡，数十人丧生人质。这是巴勒斯坦武装分子五十年来最严重的进攻之一。作为回应，以色列轰炸了加沙的目标，造成数百人死亡，以色列总理;本杰明·内塔尼亚胡;宣布;这个国家正处于战争之中;。乔·拜登总统全力支持以色列；尽管与内塔尼亚胡的关系有时不稳定，但拜登政府最近一直在努力促成以色列和沙特阿拉伯之间的和平。

;

;周六，我与《<数据》一书的作者内森·萨尔通了电话。 -offer-url="https://www.amazon.com/dp/1250854970" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www .amazon.com/dp/1250854970"}" href="https://www.amazon.com/dp/1250854970" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">;阿贝德·萨拉马一生中的一天;。”萨尔此前曾在国际危机组织担任阿拉伯-以色列项目总监，目前居住在耶路撒冷。在我们的谈话中，我们讨论了哈马斯袭击背后的计算，为什么以色列的政治影响如此难以预测，以及以色列的反应可能如何改变巴勒斯坦政治的未来。

;

;;您如何理解这次袭击的时间？;

;

;最近几周，我们看到加沙边境围栏周围的抗议活动重新开始，情况恶化卡塔尔撤回了对加沙的支持，卡塔尔与以色列在管理加沙方面密切合作。以色列还宣布暂停向加沙经济所依赖的加沙人提供工作许可证。这些都是时机的直接原因。

;

;但是，当然，很难想象哈马斯在没有大量计划的情况下能够成功并以这种方式让以色列感到惊讶。哈马斯在其信息中并没有强调加沙的状况。它强调阿克萨清真寺——以色列部长伊塔马尔·本格维尔和其他以色列人对阿克萨清真寺的访问增加，并公开宣布打算在那里建造一座寺庙等等——这对哈马斯来说是自私的，因为它宁愿被视为捍卫更伟大的巴勒斯坦事业，捍卫巴勒斯坦民族象征和穆斯林象征，而不是出于结束对加沙围困的更狭隘利益而采取行动。

;

;;至少有一名哈马斯发言人;周六表示;，这次袭击应该是对阿拉伯国家不要与以色列结盟的警告。我们最近看到阿拉伯国家和以色列之间的关系日益密切，现在正在讨论沙特阿拉伯和以色列之间的关系正常化，这在一定程度上是由美国斡旋的。您对此有何看法？;

;
;
;

;显然，哈马斯的这一行为是自杀行为。这是一次规模空前的袭击，以色列将进行比以往更大程度的报复，可能会导致我们以前从未见过的结果：不仅仅是用飞机简单地夷为平地，而且还有地面入侵和可能重新占领加沙地带。加沙部分地区。因此，明智地、有意地采取这一行动的决定来自于一种感觉：没有其他选择，也没有什么可失去的。哈马斯和整个巴勒斯坦人感到自己处于如此绝望的境地，部分原因是他们已经被本应成为其盟友的阿拉伯国家完全抛弃了。关于与沙特阿拉伯实现正常化步骤的谈判无疑让巴勒斯坦人感到他们已被放弃。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;当你说哈马斯的袭击是自杀行为时，你的意思是说这对哈马斯来说也是自杀行为吗？您的意思是这会给巴勒斯坦人民带来痛苦吗？;

;

;以上都是。我认为，这些袭击几乎肯定会造成比我们所见过的更大规模的平民死亡，而哈马斯也比以往任何时候都更严重地危及其在加沙的统治及其领导人的生命。这些图像对以色列公众来说是多么令人震惊，怎么形容都不为过。加沙由来自以色列境内城镇的难民组成，加沙超过 70% 的人口都是难民，因此难民将如潮水般卷土重来并占领他们的旧城镇，这绝对是以色列的噩梦。;

;以色列的那种程度的震惊和那种程度的军事失败——不仅仅是袭击发生了，而是你和我现在正在谈论，在袭击发生十二个多小时后，有报道称哈马斯战士已经占领了并仍在控制加沙以外的军事基地——这对任何以色列人来说都是不可理解的。从政治上讲，很难想象本届政府不会为了挽回面子而索取极高的价格。

;

;;但回到我的问题：当你第一次说这是自杀性的，这是对以色列与其阿拉伯邻国和平相处的回应。我以为你想说的是，这将引起以色列的压倒性反应，这反过来又会给阿拉伯国家，特别是沙特阿拉伯施加压力，要求他们现在不要与以色列达成协议，因为这只会如此可怕和可怕，因此哈马斯即使面临巨大的报复，也会在外交上取得一些成就。;

;
;
;

;也许哈马斯可以推迟正在进行的正常化，但是我不认为它的行动会阻碍本来会发生的正常化。当前，关系正常化还面临很大障碍，存在现实困难和突出问题。沙特人非常不喜欢拜登政府。他们宁愿把这份礼物交给共和党政府。有很多很多理由相信正常化并不像媒体报道的那样迫在眉睫。但我认为哈马斯没有任何合理的希望能够改变正常化的发生和不发生。

;

;;那为什么要这样做呢？你不需要让我相信巴勒斯坦人对局势感到完全绝望并感到有必要转向武装抵抗。但哈马斯的领导者也许不像你我那么多愁善感，他们会担心做一些可能对他们的运动来说是自杀性的事情。这就是为什么我对此感到有些惊讶。;

;

;我写了所有关于这场冲突中每个人的行为都可以通过理性的利己主义来解释的文章。这是我的 ;第一个书;。哈马斯的这一举动在我看来是令人费解的。他们将自己置于历史上任何时候都更大的危险之中。当然，这会增加对哈马斯的支持，让他们在一些人看来是英雄，这种厚颜无耻的行为可以带来政治收益，但风险太大了。以色列认为这是一种性质不同的行为。

;
;
;

;哈马斯可以发射一堆火箭，而我们已经看到这种模式，它会持续几天到几周，而它们之所以能幸存下来，是因为归根结底，以色列不想重新占领加沙。从以色列的角度来看，这是一项极其不受欢迎的任务，也是一项血腥且代价高昂的任务。然而，哈马斯明白，以色列公众和政治领导层将认为这次袭击的规模完全不同。因此，以色列将考虑采取在过去的升级中没有采取的行动，包括派遣地面部队并重新占领加沙并试图消除其领导层。

;;这是否会让您有不同的想法以色列的军事准备情况和现任以色列政府的能力如何？;

;

;自 1973 年战争以来，还没有发生过如此严重的军事失败。 1973年赎罪日，以色列遭到埃及和叙利亚的突然袭击，并成立了一个调查委员会来调查军事失败。这是以色列政治中对敌人及其意图的错误观念的比喻。每一位以色列军官的骨子里都有 1973 年的教训：不断质疑自己的前提，并做好迎接挑战的准备。因此，这不仅让以色列人对其陆军的能力产生了质疑，也让每个外部观察员都产生了质疑。太令人震惊了。这是中东最强大的军队之一。一群来自被围困贫民窟的战士冲破了围栏，占领了以色列军事基地。

;

;;有人批评内塔尼亚胡政府的国内计划损害了军事准备。您如何看待这个论点？;

;

;随着司法改革，所有这些预备役军人，特别是来自空军的预备役军人，他们说他们会拒绝服役叫起来。因此抗议者称内塔尼亚胡顽固地推行司法改革正在危及以色列的安全。这就是最近提出的党派主张。

;

;这完全是自私自利。这是司法改革反对者提出的主张。我毫不怀疑这损害了以色列的能力。但内塔尼亚胡及其盟友对此进行了反驳，那就是，好吧，我们不要否认这一事实，即这种保留的抗议活动损害了以色列的安全及其准备工作。但这应该归咎于谁呢？难道我们应该为此负责，因为我们顽强地追求我们认为完全合法的司法改革吗？还是这些预备役军人越界了？

;

;;我想你会发现这场辩论的双方都没有抓住要点？;

;

;是的，我非常不同意司法改革抗议的整个前提，这是基于双方认为以色列民主受到威胁的假设。我看不出民主的任何定义如何能够包括这样一种情况：十分之一的以色列犹太人生活在被占领土上，并拥有充分的权利——投票权、公民权利——而且，当他们往返于工作场所和家中时，他们不跨越国际边界。以色列中央统计局公布该国犹太人和阿拉伯人的人数时，列出了居住在定居点的犹太人。并没有说他们住在国外。人民在定居点投票时，不会投缺席选票；从任何意义上说，这些人都生活在以色列国境内，与数百万不同种族的人一起生活，他们被剥夺了基本公民权利。这种情况已经存在了几十年。

;
;
;

;;1973 年的战争被认为产生了非常长期的政治后果对于以色列和以色列工党来说，之后的情况就不一样了。您认为这在政治上会如何表现？目前看来，内塔尼亚胡的反对者将在这场战争继续下去的同时与他一起组建联合政府。;

;

;鉴于内塔尼亚胡的规模，这对内塔尼亚胡和本届政府来说是一个巨大的挑战。失败。尽管如此，当前联盟的反对者在政治上并不令人印象深刻，而内塔尼亚胡已经证明了自己非常熟练和有弹性。即使在发生如此规模的灾难的那天，我也不愿意预测这将导致内塔尼亚胡政治生涯的终结。

;

;1973 年产生了许多后果。其中之一是内部的，正如你所说。这是工党几十年统治地位结束的开始。但 1973 年战争最重要的后果是，它促使以色列重新评估其对埃及和坚守西奈半岛的政策。它开始采取措施与埃及达成协议；这种情况一开始反复发生，然后最终导致与埃及达成和平协议，以及以色列从西奈半岛全面撤军和定居点。

;

;;正如您所看到的来自世界各地的声明特别是欧洲和美国，您认为我们所看到的对以色列的全力支持是否表明以色列在外交上取得了一些成功？或者这个事件是如此令人震惊和可怕，以至于你无论如何都会预料到这种反应？我对收到的慰问并不感到惊讶，但并没有太多呼吁“缓和紧张局势”等。;

;

;首先，西方和美国对以色列的支持是坚定不移的，而且这完全不足为奇。就没有呼吁克制而言：以色列常常将这些视为快速结束加沙轰炸行动的信号。如果这里没有它，我的解释是相反的：这是为以色列采取报复措施开了绿灯，我们都肯定会采取报复措施。

;

;我并不认为以色列正处于困难之中。外交地放置。关于拜登政府可能多么不喜欢与最近记忆中最右翼的以色列政府合作以及在高级部长职位上公开种族主义者等问题，有很多讨论。但归根结底，拜登政府对以色列的政策是什么？它只是允许以色列加入免签证计划，这是一次令人垂涎的外交胜利，而且它几乎没有采取任何措施来阻止西岸 1100 多名贝都因人被迫流离失所。

;;几个月后巴勒斯坦政治会有何不同？;

;

;如果有人现在在他的靴子里发抖，我是马哈茂德·阿巴斯。他正在目睹约旦河西岸的市中心站出来支持哈马斯和加沙的其他组织。他和巴勒斯坦权力机构被认为与以色列密切合作，限制对以色列占领的任何形式的抵抗。因此，哈马斯声望的大幅提升对他来说是极大的威胁，就像我们在周六事件之前和之后在约旦河西岸看到的暴力事件的增加一样。

;
;
;

;;如果这对哈马斯和阿巴斯来说都极其令人担忧，那么未来是极其未知的。;

;

;很大程度上取决于以色列愿意付出多大的代价才能真正改变周五存在的局势。这就是我所说的自杀的意思。如果哈马斯理解以色列——我认为它理解——它就会在发动这次袭击之前知道以色列将考虑以前从未考虑过的选择。

;

;;你还在想什么今天呢？;

;

;我正在看媒体对这次活动的报道。十年来，我在国际危机组织工作，每次加沙局势升级时，我的大部分工作就是写一份反应性报告，因为一旦我们有任何形式的冲突，全世界的注意力都会集中在这个问题上。暴力激增。但当它不存在时，我们都会把目光移开。对我来说，在国际危机组织工作并一遍又一遍地撰写有关升​​级的同一份报告的过程使我确信我应该离开国际危机组织和此类工作。我需要做的是更多地关注根本原因，而这些根源被忽视了，我们肯定会看到越来越多的零星暴力事件爆发，双方都有平民被杀，因为我们拒绝关注暴力的实际原因。

;

;当我为一本书选择主题时，我想明确地引起世界对结构性原因的关注。人们很容易选择一些引人注目的事情，比如加沙的爆炸事件，或者哈马斯的袭击。这些都是人们关心的事情。但我故意选择了一些普通的事情，一些世界各地都发生的事情——一场车祸，一群幼儿园孩子在去游乐区的路上发生的悲惨碰撞。在这个特定系统中发生这样的事情意味着什么？在这个系统中，父母根据绿身份证或蓝身份证的不同，有不同的能力去不同的医院探望孩子？并探索被困在系统中的人们的日常生活，这是这些爆炸的真正驱动力，每隔几个月或几年就会引起我们的注意。 ♦

;The first days of the former cryptocurrency billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried's criminal trial, in lower Manhattan, unfolded during an unseasonably warm spell in early October.周三，班克曼-弗里德以喜欢穿休闲装和留着蓬乱的头发而闻名，他从布鲁克林的一所联邦监狱来到法庭，他剪着新的平头发型，穿着一套西装。 During the prosecution's opening argument, the math wunderkind, who journalists (including ;me;) have often observed jiggling his knees, sat still as the US Attorney Thane Rehn proposed the government's answer to the question that will dominate the next few weeks of courtroom proceedings: Is Sam Bankman-Fried the crypto world's equivalent of Bernie Madoff, or is he an idiosyncratic genius whose company simply became so successful so fast that he lost control of it?

;

;A little less than a year ago, Bankman-Fried had been ascendant.由于他创立的加密货币业务取得了成功，他的身家估计达到数十亿美元；他考虑有一天要买进高盛。 At the same time, as a vocal adherent of ;effective altruism;, the quasi-utilitarian ;philanthropic movement;, he pledged to give most of that money away.雷恩是一名功勋卓著的辩手，在拥挤的法庭前的讲台上发表讲话，唤起了班克曼-弗里德的浮夸，并试图将他描绘成一个两面派。雷恩说，被捕前，班克曼·弗里德住在巴哈马群岛一套价值三千万美元的顶层公寓里，与名人交往密切。 “他有财富，有权力，有影响力，”雷恩说。 “But all of that, all of it, was built on lies.”

;

;FTX, the cryptocurrency exchange that Bankman-Fried co-founded in 2019, had as swift a rise as any company in recent memory—and an even quicker fall. FTX 是作为用户可以买卖比特币和以太坊等加密货币的交易所而创建的，在鼎盛时期，FTX 的估值高达 320 亿美元。 2022 年底，该公司财务信息截图的泄露引发了人们对其偿付能力的担忧，客户急于提取资金，却发现无法提取，这一数字随之暴跌。雷恩说，当“真相开始浮出水面时，那些钱，顾客的钱，就消失了。 The defendant had taken it.”

;

;According to the government, Bankman-Fried and his associates illegally funnelled billions of dollars to another of Bankman-Fried's enterprises, the hedge fund Alameda Research, which engaged in speculative crypto trading, from as early as FTX's founding.检方称，这笔钱超过百亿美元，用于投资、购买房地产、政治捐款和企业开支。 A ;Wall Street Journal; ;investigation; based on financial filings and court documents published Saturday found that Bankman-Fried and fellow-executives had spent about eight billion dollars of FTX customer deposits. Hundreds of millions were used to purchase real estate in the Bahamas and for political and charitable donations, more than a billion dollars was invested in a Kazakhstan-based cryptocurrency-mining company, and more than two billion dollars was transmitted to FTX executives in the form of personal loans that were never repaid.

;

;Last December‚ about a month after FTX filed for bankruptcy, Bankman-Fried was arrested in the Bahamas.他在美国被指控欺诈和洗钱等罪名。他坚称自己无罪并拒绝认罪。但在审判中取得成功将是一项艰巨的任务。自他被捕以来，他在 FTX 的三名亲密同事，包括一名前恋人，已认罪并同意出庭指证他。在开庭陈词中，雷恩告诉陪审团，可能需要审查的证据包括“内部圈子”的证词、公司内部文件、FTX 与其贷方共享的财务报表，以及也许最可恶的“被告自己的证词”。话”，包括他试图删除的推文。 If Bankman-Fried is convicted on all counts, the maximum term of his sentence could exceed a hundred years.

;

;The defense's opening statement, delivered directly after Rehn's, tried to paint Bankman-Fried as a well-meaning business leader who got in over his head. “Sam 相信，并且有理由相信，FTX 向 Alameda 提供的贷款是被允许的，并有合理的担保和抵押品支持，”他的首席律师 Mark Cohen 表示。他将班克曼-弗里德描绘成一个严肃的年轻人——“一个非常努力地尝试和创造事物的人，而不是伤害它们的人。他是一个不喝酒也不聚会的数学呆子。” FTX 的垮台是由于他和他的同事必须应对不断变化的环境，常常每天做出数百个决定。 “As a result, some things got overlooked.”

;
;
;

;Cohen tried, in a plainspoken way, to explain how Alameda's and FTX's finances became entangled.他说，FTX 一度没有自己的银行账户——大概是因为加密货币公司很难找到愿意与他们合作的银行——因此无法接受客户的现金存款。所以它使用了阿拉米达账户。据科恩称，班克曼-弗里德相信他可以从这些存款中向阿拉米达或其他客户放贷。 “由于缺乏全面的风险管理功能，”科恩继续说道，包含这些存款的账户“没有按照应有的方式进行跟踪和核对。”换句话说，这些钱不是用错了，而是放错了地方。科恩说，班克曼-弗里德在每一步中都做出了他认为最好的决定，并且对这些决定保持透明。这些决定导致了灾难并不一定意味着犯罪意图。 (It's unclear how FTX's failure to build a robust risk-management arm fit into this narrative.)

;

;Later that day, the government presented its first witness, Marc-Antoine Julliard.雷恩在开场陈词中表示，班克曼-弗里德的欺诈行为既让“老练”的受害者也陷入了“普通”的受害者之中。在伦敦担任商品交易员的朱利亚德似乎属于前一类。朱利亚德作证称，在网上得知风险投资公司已向该公司投资数亿美元后，他决定通过 FTX 投资加密货币，他认为这是“信任票”。 At the time of the run on FTX, in November, 2022, Julliard's account held about eighty thousand dollars' worth of bitcoin and about twenty thousand US dollars—none of which he has been able to access since.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The most devastating testimony so far began on Thursday, when Bankman-Fried's co-founder, Gary Wang, took the stand. （在朱利亚德和王之间，政府提出了另一位证人，亚当·耶迪迪亚 (Adam Yedidia)，他是班克曼-弗里德的前大学朋友，后来成为 FTX 的软件工程师。）王和班克曼-弗里德在高中时相识，成为了朋友。数学夏令营；两人后来成为麻省理工学院的室友，班克曼-弗里德毕业五年后，他们一起创立了 FTX。在作证的第一天下午，当王在辩护席上走过班克曼-弗里德时，他直视前方。此后不久，他告诉法庭班克曼-弗里德指示他更改计算机代码；这使得 Alameda 可以几乎无限制地从 FTX 借款。 By the fall of 2022, he said, Alameda owed about fourteen billion dollars—all derived from customer funds—to the other company, with no way of paying it back.

;

;Wang's testimony paused on Friday afternoon;当周二恢复时，它可能会向密切关注该剧的大批媒体提供更多耸人听闻的细节。复杂的白领刑事案件往往会给被告带来巨大的认罪压力，因此审判很少。随着公众将 FTX 故事视为我们这个时代过度行为的象征，这一事实促使该案成为数字时代最受媒体关注的白领法律诉讼之一。 (Outside the courthouse, the street was lined with the usual television cameras and typical news-organization reporters; podcasters and Substack journalists are also covering the case. According to the crypto news site Decrypt, some half a dozen TV series and films about FTX's fall are also under way.) But, more important, Bankman-Fried's trial will also hold valuable lessons for consumers, financial regulators, and the crypto industry.

;

;Andrew Entwistle, one of the attorneys representing FTX investors in a class-action lawsuit who also worked on litigation related to the Bernie Madoff case, thinks that the suit could be a turning point. “我在麦道夫打交道和交谈过的每个人都明白，他们有自己的特定账户，这些账户持有证券和其他资产。当然那不是真的，”恩特威斯尔告诉我。 “你会收到账户报表并查看仪表板，但这些都不是真实的。所有这些钱都被转移到其他地方了。”恩特威斯尔认识购买加密货币的普通人，包括“警察、消防员和当地治安官”。 “我们正处于一个人人都是投资者的新世界。很少有经纪业务是你无法通过手机查看的。”他说。 “重要的是，当这样的案例出现时，它会敲响警钟——作为一个小投资者，你总是处于严重的信息匮乏之中。 And hopefully to regulators, to say, Hey, we should be making sure that there's integrity in our financial institutions and in the markets.”

;

;There are also lessons for the industry that made Bankman-Fried famous.加密货币长期以来一直在与自己的声誉作斗争，许多人主要将其视为洗钱者和有组织犯罪分子的避风港。当班克曼-弗里德 (Bankman-Fried) 运营 FTX 时，他的核心目标之一似乎就是使其合法化。在他被起诉后，他所建立的任何信誉都被摧毁了。 “我认为这个行业还有一线希望。范德比尔特大学法学教授耶沙·亚达夫 (Yesha Yadav) 告诉我，现在是真正让该行业摆脱这种从一开始就笼罩在该行业阴云密布的名声的时刻了。 “这是一个驱除 FTX 幽灵的机会，并以非常有利于客户、有利于监管、高度透明的方式向前发展。这是可能发生的时刻。” ♦

;In broad daylight on Saturday, Palestinian militants, led by Hamas, the Islamist group that controls Gaza, rampaged through southern Israeli communities, spraying bullets at motorists and passersby, attacking a desert rave, raiding civilian homes and military bases, and kidnapping Israeli soldiers and civilians. Images shared on social media showed abandoned bodies strewn on highways, fighters taking elderly men and women captive, and young men blowing up Army vehicles. The unprecedented violence has resulted in nearly seven hundred Israelis dead and more than two thousand injured. (The Israeli Embassy in Washington, DC, has said that dozens of soldiers and civilians were taken hostage. ) The scenes drew comparisons to the Yom Kippur War, of 1973, when, on the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, Egypt and Syria launched an unexpected assault, making breakthroughs into the Sinai Peninsula and Golan Heights; a ceasefire was later called.

;

;In response Saturday's attack, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared that Israel was ;at war; and announced that its troops would “forcefully avenge this dark day.” The Israeli Army retaliated with a series of air strikes across Gaza, targeting infrastructure that it said belongs to Hamas, including a fourteen-story residential building in Gaza City. Health authorities in the territory said that three hundred and seventy people have been killed in air strikes and gun battles and twenty-two-hundred have been wounded. As of Sunday, Gaza, which for the past sixteen years has been under an Israeli-Egyptian blockade and faces immense unemployment, severe poverty, and highly inadequate power and water resources, has effectively become a war zone.

;

;Before the start of the weekend, Yoni Asher, a thirty-seven-year-old real-estate consultant from Ganot Hadar, a community in central Israel, had said goodbye to his wife, Doron, and their daughters, Raz, who is four, and Aviv, who is two. They had travelled to Kibbutz Nir Oz, in southern Israel, to spend the last day of Sukkot at Doron's mother's house. “I stayed back at our home because I had work to finish and spent the holiday with my side of the family,” he told me late Saturday night. “I had expected all of them to return tonight.” But early Saturday morning, news surfaced that his mother-in-law's community had been infiltrated by Palestinian militants. “I immediately called and texted my wife,” he said. “She was sheltering with my daughters, her mom, and her mom's partner in ;mamad;, the fortified safe room in her mom's apartment.”

;

;I spoke with Asher on Zoom, at around 3 ;AM; Israeli time on Sunday. He looked weary. Bags were forming under his eyes. But he seemed remarkably composed, given the nightmare that had befallen his family. The militants had discovered his wife and daughters, along with his mother-in-law, Efrat Katz, and taken them hostage. Asher had since been speaking to whomever he could in the Israeli press, pleading for the government and international community to help rescue his loved ones. During our conversation, which was translated from Hebrew and edited for length and clarity, Asher told me, “I'll leave no rock unturned until we're reunited.”

;

;“Around 10 ;AM;, I spoke to my wife again. She was whispering this time. She told me terrorists had broken into the apartment. The call ended, and I prayed they would be spared. When I tried to reach her again, no one answered. In a panic, I went into my wife's Google account to track her phone. What I saw made me fear the worst—it was showing it had gone from Nir Oz to Khan Younis, in Gaza. When reporters called me for an update, I told them that I hoped her phone was there but not her or my daughters.

;

;“About an hour later, friends sent me a video from social media confirming something I'd wished to never see. The terrorists had kidnapped them. My wife, daughters, and mother-in-law were in the back of a metal cart, being taken hostage. One of the terrorists was trying to cover my wife's hair with a cloth, but the moment I saw the video I had no doubt it was them.

;
;
;

;“I'm trying everything I can to raise awareness about my family's case and to help bring them home as soon as possible. I've been in touch with the press all day, doing interview after interview hoping that the authorities will do something to save my family. I also have been attempting to reach officials in the government and security establishment, but nobody other than a social worker has contacted me yet. I haven't eaten or slept in fifteen hours. I don't think someone can eat in this situation or even think about eating. All I can do is reach out to everyone who will listen and share the names and photos of my family.

;

;“I'm in a different world than the one I was in yesterday. I think everyone who is a parent of small children wouldn't want to think about their loved ones being taken by Hamas. So all I can focus on is them getting through this situation and back to safety. But, of course, like every other parent, I'm terrified and fearful—I worry about what will happen in the coming days. The uncertainty is so hard to deal with. It's extremely difficult. I don't know how much time it will take to bring them home. Not to mention, when you're reaching out to officials all day and no one responds, it feels like you've been abandoned. That you're in no man's land. It almost feels like there's nobody I can rely on.” [;On Sunday, he said he heard from the police and the foreign ministry, but no one could provide him with new information.;]

;

;“My request of Hamas is that they don't harm my daughters and family and that they release the women and children before starting any kind of negotiations. I know of other women and children who have been taken by Hamas, as well, and they need to free them. It's inhumane to be holding them, but I know that Hamas isn't committed to international law. It's not a state within the international system. We can only really pray that the people taken hostage are OK

;

;“My daughters are amazing—the best a dad could wish for. They have a lot of energy and they're warm and curious. They are close to each other and enjoy playing together. Raz, who has curly golden hair, loves singing and dancing. She learns songs quickly and understands them in both Hebrew and English. She likes 'Unicorn,' by Noa Kirel. We sang this song in the car together over the summer. She was saying, 'Daddy, it goes like this, not like that.' She paid attention to every error I made with the lyrics and key, and made us repeat the song from the beginning.

;

;“Like any other child, Aviv likes chocolate. She's always looking forward to finding which chocolate my wife or I bring home. She has grown up quickly but she likes to run around the house.

;

;“I hope that they will be strong, that they will get through this situation staying safe and come home as soon as possible.” ♦

;You can eat any old sandwich for breakfast, but a breakfast sandwich is something particular, a category defined by form: there must be eggs, there must be cheese, and they must be swaddled together in the tender bosom of some form of bread, or at least something sufficiently bread-adjacent. Compositions of striking ambition and thrilling complexity can be built around this fundamental armature, but in my breakfast-sandwich journeys I've been burned more times than I can count: by too-chewy bacon, oversweet tomato confit, fussy and pointless garnishes, the inexplicable inclusion of sausage links, which rolled off the bread like logs from a timber lorry. A breakfast sandwich is a matter of balance and texture, but also urgency; it should be a snap to order, quick to prepare, a ritualized pleasure to consume. A worthy specimen is likely available at a bodega or a coffee cart near you, but if you're game to level up here are three that are, in my opinion, among the best in New York City.

;
;The Mortadella Pancake at Win Son Bakery
;

;The simple, honest truth is that the best breakfast meat is mortadella. Velvety and savory, a stylish gentleman's pink, the rich emulsion of pork and spices (arguably a pâté!) is unmatched as a complement to the similarly voluptuous flavors of egg and cheese. Take the Mortadella Pancake at Win Son Bakery, the more casual offshoot of East Williamsburg's wonderful Taiwanese American restaurant Win Son, in which silk-thin slices of mortadella join a crêpe-like scrambled egg, melty raclette, and slivers of pickly hot peperoncini. That could have been enough (;dayenu;), but then! The whole thing is wrapped up in an enormous scallion pancake, then pressed on the griddle to supreme toastiness; the flaky, pastry-like savory pancake is a perfect contrapunto to the unctuousness of its contents. If you eschew mortadella, a position I can neither endorse nor comprehend, there are variants made with bacon, pastrami beef, and shrimp patties, and a vegetarian version with ;jiǔcài; (Chinese chives). All of them are served with a sidecar of dreamy, creamy dipping sauce that's fiery and funky thanks to ;doufu ru; (fermented tofu) and fiery raw ginger.

;
;The Breakfast Sandwich at Court Street Grocers
;

;It's rare, for me, to find satisfaction in a breakfast sandwich that doesn't also contain some kind of meat—I need that extra hit of salt and fat, the deep savoriness, the textural oomph. At any of the city's four Court Street Grocers locations, you can get a breakfast sandwich with bacon or house-made chorizo, and it's great, but—to my surprise, and delight—it's not nearly as great as the version without. It's the eggs that make this sandwich such a joy to devour: they're fluffy, melty, buttery, tender without being runny, and cooked with not so much as a hint of a sear mark or a brown spot of overcooking. I'd frost a cake with them, if I could. Heaped onto a halved ciabatta roll and enrobed in a layer of melted white cheddar, they attain a multidimensional richness that genuinely changed my relationship to scrambled eggs. The pile of arugula on top is an inspired addition: the sharp greens slice through what could otherwise be too much butteriness, too much softness, readying your palate for another bite.

;
;;NEO; on a Bialy at Barney Greengrass
;

;The lox scrambled with eggs and onions—;LEO;, for those in the know—at this century-old Upper West Side appetizing shop is a deservedly famous dish, but allow me to swing the spotlight a few lines higher on the menu. There, you'll find the ;NEO;, which uses Nova instead of the much saltier, much more face-punchy belly lox of the more famous variant. This preference isn't a matter of sodium aversion; it's a statement of connoisseurship. Lox is salmon that's been salt-cured; its flavor is saline and intense. This aggressiveness has a time and a place—there's a reason lox is so often cushioned by cream cheese and paired with sharp garnishes like tart tomato or raw red onion—but, in the ;LEO;, its brashness totally overwhelms what ought to be a three-part harmony. Nova is also a salt-cured salmon, but then the fish is kissed with smoke. The flavor is sweeter, more subtle, a more elegant counterpart to sautéed onion, and its gentler texture is far more lovely against the eggs. The ;NEO; at Barney Greengrass is one of the city's great breakfast plates—but is it a sandwich? It is the way I eat it: get a bialy on the side, split and toasted, and pile on as much of the scramble as the bread will hold. There are few more exquisite ways to start a morning. ♦

;When “Star Trek: The Next Generation” premièred, in 1987, a newspaper referred to its leading man as an “unknown British Shakespearean actor.” Patrick Stewart was already forty-seven and had spent fourteen years as a full-time member of the Royal Shakespeare Company. But he had known nothing like the fame that playing Jean-Luc Picard—captain of the USS Enterprise and model of enlightened masculinity—would soon bring him. When he showed up on set the next day, a castmate had taped a sign on his trailer door that read “;BEWARE: UNKNOWN BRITISH SHAKESPEAREAN ACTOR;.”

;

;Stewart is now eighty-three, having spent nearly half his life as Jean-Luc Picard, and he's been reflecting on the unlikely trajectory that brought him from an impoverished childhood in the North of England to the final frontier. As a boy in Mirfield, an industrial town in Yorkshire, he had no hot running water, refrigeration, or toilet in his house. “Mirfield boys like me weren't expected to have lofty ambitions. Certainly none that would ever take me into outer space,” he writes in his new autobiography, “;Making It So;.”

;

;“I am in unknown territory,” Stewart told me recently. “I've never written anything before, other than maybe a two-hundred-word introduction or a thank-you letter.” He was in a sitting room in a hotel in Manhattan, where his third wife, the musician Sunny Ozell, was topping off his coffee. Stewart had been asked to write his life story before, but he always declined. “I never had the time to do it. But then my agent, early in 2020, said, 'Look, Patrick, there ;is; no work. It's going to be a shut down everywhere, and it could last for months. This is the only window, so why not give it a go? If it doesn't work out, we'll just return the advance, and you can go back to doing jigsaw puzzles.”

;

;As Stewart spoke, his sonorous voice filled the room, and his thick eyebrows—which seem magnified, being the only visible hair on his head—danced above his eyes. Stewart is a born storyteller, as anyone who has seen him perform his solo stage version of “;A Christmas Carol;” can attest. I first met him thirteen years ago, when he was acting in the David Mamet play “A Life in the Theatre” and met me in his dressing room, for a ;Talk of the Town interview; about some of the unknown British stage actors with whom he had worked early in career. I remember sitting spellbound, asking questions that were answered with long, luxurious monologues, rich with reminiscence. That's the feeling I got while reading “Making It So,” and again when we talked last month. (In deference to the ;SAG-AFTRA; strike, we discussed “Star Trek” only in the context of his memoir.) Our conversation, which has been edited for length and clarity, covers his lifelong fascination with Shakespeare, his encounters with rock stars and Old Hollywood royalty, and getting high—in more ways than one.

;

;;Your whole life is so vividly remembered, going back to your early childhood. As you were writing, did you need to do anything special to conjure the detail? Did you have to do research into yourself?;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;A kind of research, Michael. I hadn't read many memoirs, two or three perhaps. I'm a great novel lover. I've been passionate about books since I was five or six years old and was introduced to the local library in my small town in the North of England. We had no television in my house. We had no record player. All we had was BBC Radio. And so I used the library as my source of not just entertainment but also education as I got older. My education was very basic, and for years I felt uncomfortable about that, when I found myself working with Oxbridge men and women and so forth.

;
;
;

;For a couple of days before I began writing, I just let what memories that I had of my early life [come]. Let me start at the beginning of the story and set a scene, which may take a lot of people somewhat by surprise, to find that I grew up in the relative poverty that I did. We lived in a house called a one-up, one-down, where there was one room downstairs, one room upstairs, and the front door opened onto a cinder yard. When I was a child, it was occupied by myself and my older brother, Trevor, and my gorgeous, kind, sweet, loving, funny mother. The first five years of my life were bliss. Heaven on a stick!

;

;By opening up those doors, things trickled and then ended up flooding in.

;

;;One of your earliest memories is when you encountered your first peach. Can you tell me what happened?;

;

;My father had come home from war in 1945. He came home in uniform, and he kept his uniform for a long time. We had very simple holidays. We would go either to the North sea towns or to the west side of the UK, facing the Irish Sea: Morecambe, Blackpool. We were in Blackpool walking along the promenade—my father, my brother, my mother, and me—and we went past a fruit-and-vegetable store. My father peeled off, and then in a few minutes came back with his hands behind his back and said to me, “Patrick, close your eyes and hold out your hand.” And something was put into my hand which I didn't like the feeling of at all. I thought it was a creature or something. And I pulled my hand away. My father yelled at me, “Don't do that!” I opened my eyes and found that it was a fruit I'd never seen before, which was now smashed on the sidewalk. And my father hit me. I think it was the only occasion he actually hit ;me;. He was a hitter, but I think that was the only time. So I have always associated that fruit with that moment, an embarrassing and uncomfortable moment. There were actually many. I got used to them.

;

;;You write, “It's taken me decades of analysis, beginning in the late 1980s, to understand and cope with the impact of the violence, fear, shame, and guilt I experienced as a child.” What did you come to understand about why your father was behaving the way he was?;

;
;
;

;When I was growing up, I never talked about my background, because I was so embarrassed. Our neighbors knew what my father could do and would do, and they were well aware of the shouting and yelling that he produced. Somebody—I think it might have been my doctor—said, “It's very likely that your father is suffering from shell shock.” Well, they didn't treat for shell shock in those days. A few years ago, the BBC asked me to do that show “Who Do You Think You Are?” On that program, there was an historian who specialized in medical conditions brought about by being in the military, and he told me that there is no doubt whatsoever that my father had suffered from PTSD Well, there was no PTSD back in the nineteen-forties. So my father was sick, and it was the sickness that made him lose control as he did. He was a “weekend alcoholic.” Friday evening, he began drinking, and that went through until Sunday evening. Those were the times when he was dangerous to be around.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;You write that acting was a “safe space.” Can you describe how you first discovered Shakespeare?;

;

;My schoolteacher when I was twelve years old was responsible for all of that. His name was Cecil Dormand. Cecil first put a copy of a Shakespeare play into my hand. I'd never heard of it. It was “The Merchant of Venice.” He went around the classroom, handing copies, and said, “Patrick—Shylock.” I'd never heard of Shylock, of course. He said, “All right, start reading. Act IV, Scene 1.” And every single one of us then dives into the script, but I'd be surprised if there were any of us comprehending what we were reading. And we were reading to ;ourselves;. Cecil Dormand shouted out, “Not to yourselves, you idiots! This is a play! It's drama! It's life! Start again, and this time, read it ;out loud;.” And we did. I had no idea what I was talking about, and there were words I had never encountered. The first speech that Shylock has in that scene is about twenty-five lines long, so it was a struggle. But something had penetrated me that I had never experienced before. That was the beginning.

;
;
;

;;And then at some point you were both doing amateur theatricals and working as a newspaper reporter?;

;

;I was. My headmaster had pulled some strings with the editor of our local newspaper, the ;Dewsbury and District Reporter;, and I was called in one day and told, “They've offered you a job, but as a very junior reporter.” The building we were in was pointed, and the journalists' room was at the very narrowest end. Sitting in front of the end window was a man called Charlie Pickles, the subeditor. And he was difficult. We would hear him sigh and groan and mutter to himself. I was given calls that I should make every week, some of them twice a week. One was to the owner of a pub. One was to a working-men's-club secretary. This is where the gossip came from. I was able to write one or two things, and there was a groaning and sighing, and he would correct it and cross out stuff.

;

;Well, time went by, and I was finally called to the editor's office. Henry Wilson was his name. And he had found out that I was missing evening assignments, largely because by the time I was fifteen I was working with a handful of amateur drama groups. They rehearsed in the evening, so I used to have to find a substitute, who would take over for me and then write the piece in my name. I was found out when there was a big fire in a weaving mill, and the editor and the subeditor called one another. They said, “Patrick is in the council house next door. We've got an eyewitness!” Well, of course, I wasn't there. I was in another town rehearsing. They found that out the next morning, and I was in deep shit. I was sent to the editor's office, and he said, “Look, Patrick, I think you could do quite well in this job. But you have got to focus on what you're doing. You've got to give up these amateur theatricals, because you can't do both.” And I said, “Well, I'll say goodbye right now, then, Mr. Wilson.” He looked at me in astonishment. I packed up my typewriter that same afternoon and never went back.

;

;;This eventually brought you to drama school, and I want to ask you about baldness, because you write that you started losing your hair at seventeen and were as bald as you are now at nineteen, which must have been rather alarming. How did you react?;

;

;I hated losing my hair. I had a wonderful, thick head of hair. My father was bald. I'd seen photographs of my grandfather—he was bald. So I knew what lay ahead for me. I also knew that it meant the chance of me getting a girlfriend was getting thinner, as my hair was thinning. So I struggled, and I went to hairdressers, and I had treatments, which did nothing at all but cost me a lot of money that I couldn't afford. Then one day, when I was already at drama school, there was a Hungarian chap who had come because of the revolution. He was a director, I think in Budapest. He said to me one day, “Patrick, I know you're worried about losing your hair, but it's going to be who you are. Why don't you just cut it all off?” And I said, “Absolutely not. I'm trying to ;keep; it.” A couple of days later, I'd gone to his house, and all of a sudden he grabbed me by the arms, and his wife approached me with a pair of scissors. I knew immediately what they were going to do. I struggled and yelled and cursed. And she cut my hair off, my long hair which I used to comb over my head. Then, when she'd done it, he said, “Now you be yourself!” Which was exactly what he should have said, because I was hiding.

;

;When I finished my drama school and started going for professional auditions, knowing how hard our regional theatre was, I would go to the audition wearing my hairpiece, my toupee. Usually, you perform two pieces for an audition. I'd perform the first one, and they'd say, “OK, let's see the second one. What is it?” As I was telling them what I was going to do, I used to remove my hairpiece, and they would gasp. I would say, “You've got a choice. You could have another actor, or you could have two actors for the price of one.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;I'm sure you have so many fans approaching you in life—“Star Trek” people, theatre fans—but do you get particular kinds of comments from bald men?;

;

;Yes. How many times have I been spoken to in the street by somebody who would pull off his cap, revealing a bald head, and say, “You saved my life!” As luck would have it, my wife and I had this conversation only a couple of days ago, and she admitted to me that she had always been attracted to bald men, from her teen-age years. I said, “Oh, at last! I now understand why you had the nerve to let me take you out.”

;
;
;

;;Your training in drama school and in your early career in the British theatre seems almost diametrically opposed to what was happening in America at the time, which was the rage for Method acting. You write, “ 'Living' or 'becoming' the role was never part of our vocabulary or curriculum.” What was your feeling about Method acting, and did you ever wind up drawing on it?;

;

;I drew on it immensely, but exclusively by selecting the films I saw [as an adolescent]. I'd fallen in love with Technicolor, and then one night I went to my local cinema, and the first thing that hit me was that it was in black-and-white. I wanted to see a Technicolor film. I went in to see it. It was called “On the Waterfront.” I hadn't heard of any of the actors in it, but their names were Marlon Brando, Eva Marie Saint, Rod Steiger. I had never seen that kind of work on a screen before. I was at first disappointed, and then intrigued. It was as though I was watching a documentary—it was so real, so truthful. And I became enraptured by what I discovered. Later, it was explained to me that these were all Method actors. When I learned that, I began to look into the Method and read Stanislavski and so forth. It became a guiding light, though, to begin with, I wasn't very good at it, because I wasn't being trained like that. I know that Duncan Ross, the principal of my school, did talk to us often about our performances coming from inside us, not from the outside. In other words, the opposite of Method was demonstration. So I learned not to demonstrate a role but to live it.

;

;;You write about playing Leontes in “The Winter's Tale” with the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1981. It's a very tricky role, because he's this psychopath who ruins his own life through pettiness and jealousy, and you needed to reach for something that was maybe more Method. How did you figure out how to play that part?;

;

;It was with the help of a director [Ronald Eyre] who had offered me the role. This character was a horrible guy—I just couldn't connect with him. I didn't know what to do. It was my first leading role with the Royal Shakespeare Company, so I was excited by that, but confused about the play itself. One day in the greenroom at the RSC, I saw sitting alone Dame Peggy Ashcroft, who was without any question the most important actress in the UK for a good number of years. I said to her, “Dame Peg, may I sit down? I've got a problem.” I told her about the offer I'd had, and she said, “Stop, stop! He's a dreadful man. The audience won't like him. Nobody will like you. Patrick, don't do it!” I breathed a sigh of relief. Well, if that's what Dame Peggy Ashcroft says, she must be right! So I called the director and said, “Thank you for the offer. I'm very flattered, but I have to turn it down.” He said, “Patrick, can we meet?” When we got together, he said, “Look, Patrick, there's something I have to tell you that may be hard to hear, but I believe it very strongly. I know that Leontes is inside you. All you're going to have to do is let him out.” Nobody had ever said anything like that to me before in my life.

;

;;Where did you find Leontes within you?;

;

;Suppressed anger, suppressed rage, sadness. Some touch of hatred, here and there. I don't know if my director knew the details of my childhood or my upbringing. Maybe somebody had told him, or maybe he had seen it himself. I looked inside myself and focussed on those feelings that I'd had that were perhaps closer to Leontes than they were to Patrick Stewart. And I lived the role. I have a very dear friend in Southern California who was an English professor at UCLA when I met him, and he came to see “The Winter's Tale” twice. The second time, we went out for dinner. The woman who played my wife got rave reviews, as did another actor who played one of the comedy roles, and mine had been sort of, “Yeah, yeah.” And my friend, Professor David Rodes, said, “More people would have enjoyed what you did if they hadn't felt that it was too private to be on a stage.” Of course, I took that as a huge compliment.

;

;;Then came the major turning point of your career, being cast as Jean-Luc Picard in “Star Trek: The Next Generation.” You write that you rewatched the series as part of your writing process and that it was an “emotional roller coaster.” Why was that?;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;I watched the first and second seasons, and I was disappointed with what I saw, particularly the first season, and specifically my work. I found it lacking intimacy. It was very authoritative, but there were few other qualities in him. I tell the story of calling a meeting of my principal fellow cast members and telling them that I thought we were not disciplined enough, that we should not be fooling about on the set as much as we were but taking everything seriously. And one of the cast members said, “Oh, come on, Patrick, we've got to have some fun.” And I thumped the chair and said, “We are not here to have ;fun;.” Which they have never let me forget. They taught me so much about loosening up and being freer. All this fed into the feeling I had about Marlon Brando and Rod Steiger. I think that the work that we did got better through the third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh seasons.

;
;
;

;;It's interesting to hear that, because you seem like a very fun person. In the past ten years, you've become a social-media star: eating your first ;New York pizza slice;, dressed in a ;lobster costume; in your bathtub for Halloween. You've let the world see Patrick Stewart's silly side. How did you get into social media?;

;

;My wife and my PR company, ID PR. They would often talk to me about social media. It wasn't in my world at all, and I thought there was something fundamentally silly about it. And then when the time came to promote “Picard” or other work that I've done, they began to encourage me to explore social media. My wife, Sunny, was very experienced in the Internet, and she had a lot of good ideas.

;

;;Can you tell me about the ;video; you two made, where you demonstrated the “quadruple take”?;

;

;I'll be very honest with you, it partly came about because of . 。 。 [;Sir Patrick Stewart mimes smoking a joint.;] One weekend afternoon, when we were staying out in the country, we had a hit of weed. With me, it was literally one hit, because I have very low tolerance. I don't know how the quadruple take came up, but I showed it to my wife, and she said, “Quick, let me shoot that! Do it all again!” So I did, and she said, “I think we should post this.” Oh, it made me squirm! To my astonishment, it absolutely exploded.

;

;;For the last part of our interview, I want to play a game I'm calling Drop That Name. I'm going to throw out a name, and I'd love to hear a story about the person. The first one is Paul McCartney.;

;

;Popular music has never played a big part in my life, and yet the Beatles impacted me. I thought they were astonishing. I knew they were four working-class lads from Liverpool. OK, so they were Lancashire, not Yorkshire, like me! [In the mid-sixties,] I was working at Bristol Old Vic Theatre, and there was a young actress in the company—we all knew that she was the girlfriend of Paul McCartney, but nobody ever talked about it. One day, we learned that Paul had come down to Bristol and was going to see the show that night. A few days before that, most of the principal actors had been in the local pub having lunch, and we played a game: If you were given a million pounds, what's the first thing you would buy? When they came to me, I said, “Oh, there's no question. An Aston Martin DB4.” They were very expensive and beautiful cars, and I've always been a car enthusiast. And so, on the Saturday night that we knew Paul was in the audience, I was in my very tiny dressing room. There was a knock on my door, and I was still in my underwear. I said, “Come on in,” and there was Paul McCartney. He said, “I understand you're a fan of Aston Martins. Here, drive this.” And he threw me a bunch of keys.

;

;Well, still gasping at the sight of Paul McCartney standing outside my dressing-room door, I said, “No, no, I can't.” He said, “I'll tell you what—take us both for a ride. I've never been to Bath in my life. So you can drive us to Bath and back.” So we went out, and there at the end of the alleyway that led to the stage door was this silver Aston Martin. It wasn't a DB4—it was a DB;5;! And I drove them the twelve miles to Bath and brought them home. Paul kept saying, “Come on, put your foot down!” I didn't want to, because I was so nervous. I thought, If I crash, all I will be remembered for is that I am the man who killed Paul McCartney and nothing else.

;

;Years and years went by, and I was coming out of a rehearsal room in Covent Garden and saw Paul McCartney pop out of another door and start walking towards me. And he said, “Patrick Stewart! DB5! You drove my car!”

;
;
;

;;The next dropped name is Vivien Leigh.;

;

;When I was twenty, the London Old Vic signed me up to do a tour of the world doing three plays, all of which would star Vivien Leigh. Now, Vivien Leigh in those days was still a huge star, and had won Academy Awards. I said yes before I knew the details of the offer. In the three plays accumulated together, I had a total of four and a half lines! But I was getting a pretty good salary, thirty-five pounds a week. One of the plays was about Marguerite Gautier, a beautiful nineteenth-century upper-class prostitute, and Vivien was to play this role. I was to play her lover, a wealthy elderly man. However, it turned out that he only had one scene, and that scene was silent. I arrived outside her door, which led into a box where Marguerite was sitting in a theatre. All they would see would be me going in and her gesturing for me to come in, then me bending over her hand and kissing it, and then the doors closed. The very first time we did this, I thought, My God, I'm going to be alone with Vivien Leigh! We were in the semi-dark [after the scene], because we couldn't get out of this box until that section of the play came to a halt. And she said, “Patrick, dear boy, sit down here and tell me, what have you been doing today?” I was so dazzled.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;We met like that every week for about fifteen months. Our conversations became pleasanter, funnier. I wouldn't say sexier, because she was a very properly behaved woman, and her boyfriend at the time was in the company as well. And she came to my twenty-first birthday party. I still have the amber-colored cotton handkerchief that she gave me as a gift, which was soaked in her perfume.

;

;;Incredible. OK, the next name is Al Gore.;

;

;I was doing a film [in 2000], and the director of the studio said, “Patrick, Al Gore is going to come and make a speech on one of our stages here. I've learned he's a 'Star Trek' fan, so would you mind being the person to introduce him to the audience?” And I said, “Of course. I admire him very much.” He was lovely, very warm, not aloof at all. I introduced him, and he came on and got a great round of applause. I stood in the wings and watched him. But what I saw I had uncomfortable feelings about, because as he started speaking he put one hand into a pocket and talked, and then he would take the hand out of the pocket and gesture and put his other hand into his pocket. He did this all the way through his speech, moving from hand to hand, and it looked too casual. It didn't look like the leader of a party, speaking about becoming President of the United States.

;

;So, when his speech was over, I said, “Could I just make one suggestion? When you put your hands into your pockets, you look as though you're showing how relaxed and comfortable you are. But, if you don't put your hands in your pockets and just stand there and gesture, you're being open, freer, and we're looking at a man who is liberated.” And he said, “Thank you very much. That's great advice.” Well, I watched other moments in his campaign, and he was still putting his hands into his pockets. Then, a few years ago, I went to an event. With a glass of wine in my hand, I suddenly felt a tap on my shoulder. There he was: Al Gore. And he said, “If I had listened to you, I might be President of the United States.”

;

;;Next name drop: Whoopi Goldberg.;

;

;In Season Two of “Next Generation,” I was informed that Whoopi Goldberg was joining the cast. She had just been nominated for an Academy Award. I thought, Why would she want to join a sci-fi series that's already been running for a year? And she was lovely—warm and friendly, and, of course, amusing. One day, they were lighting a scene or changing scenery, and she was sitting alone. So I sat beside her and said, “Whoopi, I don't understand why you agreed to do this.” And she told me the story of when she was a child, what the original “Star Trek” had meant to her, with Leonard Nimoy and Bill Shatner. And she said, “There was also a Black woman in the cast [Nichelle Nichols]. And it made me think, One of us must have made it.” It was her presence not just in the role but in the ;future;—one of us is going to make it.我喜欢那个。 And we've become close friends ever since.

;
;
;

;;The next one is Sting.;

;

;Oh, Lord. This is the most embarrassing one. We were filming “Dune” [in 1983], and I learned that there was someone called Sting joining the cast. I thought, ;Sting;? That's a weird name. I'd never heard it. He showed up a few days later, incredibly handsome guy. One day, like Whoopi, he was just sitting on his own, and I went over and said, “We haven't really met. My name is Patrick Stewart. I've been told you're a musician. What do you play?” And he said, “Bass.” I said, “You know, I've often wondered why people choose to carry that huge instrument around. I mean, some of them are bigger than they are! Why not play the flute or something like that?” He laughed. And I said, “Well, are you with a band?” And he said, “Yes, the Police.” And I said, “You play with a police band?” He understood that I didn't know who the hell he was. I mean, he couldn't have been a bigger star.

;

;;Sir Ian McKellen.;

;

;Ian is one of my very closest and dearest friends. He performed our wedding ceremony, beautifully. One day, I was in Covent Garden in London, and there he was, walking in the other direction. He said, “What are you doing?” And I said, “I'm about to start rehearsing 'Macbeth.' ” I was a little awkward saying that, because he had been the Macbeth of my generation, in a production that he did with Judi Dench. And he said, “Oh, can I give you one piece of advice? The line 'Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow'—the important word is ;and;.” “Oh, I see.” He said, “Yes, 'tomorrow ;and; tomorrow ;and; tomorrow.' ” He did this on the street in Covent Garden—we got some heads turning, because people were recognizing the two of us. That piece of advice opened up the role to me. Thank you, Sir Ian.

;

;;Finally, Queen Elizabeth II.;

;

;I have met Her Late Majesty several times, on occasions of contrast in formality, maybe at a Buckingham Palace garden party. I then, to my astonishment, was offered a knighthood. And I was thrilled when I learned that the person who was going to knight me would be Her Majesty, because when I got my OBE it had been presented to me by Prince Charles, who is, I find, a delightful and remarkable person. On the day that I was knighted, she performed the ceremony, and I managed to do it without falling over or tripping on the carpet. When it was over, with everyone who was receiving an award that day, she then had a little chat. She said to me, with a nice smile on her face, “And how long have you been doing this?” And I said, “A very long time, Your Majesty.” ♦

;At seven this morning, our son and daughter waded into our bedroom, a sleepy Saturday in Tel Aviv, the tail end of the long Sukkot holiday. We all snuggled together in bed, bleary-eyed. The kids started a game that soon turned into low-grade squabble, when, suddenly, an air-raid siren blared. We ducked into our building's stairwell, our “safe space” for lack of any other in this old area of the city. Some neighbors were already there, in their pajamas, everyone smiling at one another awkwardly. We spoke of previous rounds of rocket fire, all of which had been intercepted by the Israeli military to a high degree, so panic was not in the air; even the kids were acting blasé. But then we opened our phones.

;

;Surreal sights and early reports from around the country began to trickle in: Israeli vehicles had been taken over by Palestinian militants, and were barrelling through southern Israeli cities; ski-masked terrorists were shooting indiscriminately at oncoming cars and into homes in Israeli towns. Several gunmen were seen paragliding across the border, and there were news reports that an Israeli military base had been commandeered by Hamas. Friends posted about their relatives living in kibbutzim on the Gaza border whose homes had been raided while they were huddled inside with small children, pleading for help. Images emerged purporting to show four Israeli men, stripped down to their underwear on a sidewalk of an unspecified southern city, militants standing next to them, holding rifles over the Israelis' heads. The coming hours and days will tell us the details, the facts, the numbers—but the fear is immediate.

;

;According to the Israeli military, more than two thousand rockets have been fired from the Gaza Strip since early this morning. At least one hundred Israelis have been reported killed. More than nine hundred injured Israelis have been hospitalized, some critically—but those numbers are expected to rise. The health ministry in Gaza, which is run by Hamas, reported that a hundred and ninety-eight Palestinians had been killed in the hours since the escalation began. As I'm writing this, dozens of militants are still storming through the streets of Israel. Palestinian gunmen continue to infiltrate Israel's border fence with Gaza, which is now effectively breached, including by bulldozer. At least twelve communities around the country are still under siege, according to Israel's Channel 12. Footage has been released of senior Hamas leaders gathered together in a room, wearing suits, intently watching the images of war on a television screen, clearly content.

;
;
;

;Some five hours after the morning's events began, Israel declared a state of war.

;

;“Citizens of Israel, we are at war,” Prime Minister ;Benjamin Netanyahu; said, in a video message recorded in Tel Aviv. “Not an operation, not a round [of fighting] but at war. This morning Hamas initiated a murderous surprise attack against the state of Israel and its citizens.” Yoav Gallant, the defense minister, said: “Hamas made a grave mistake this morning and started a war against the State of Israel. IDF soldiers are fighting the enemy at all the infiltration sites.” Gallant also approved a wide-scale call-up of military reservists for service. Among them is my nephew, whose mother—my older sister—was just then busy uninstalling ;Giacomettis; from the walls of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, where she works, for safekeeping amid the rocket fire.

;

;Sooner or later, there will be the inevitable discussion about how Hamas was able to launch such a devastating surprise attack, which comes exactly fifty years after Israel was caught flat-footed in what became known as the Yom Kippur War. There will also be time to note the cost of the Israeli occupation: the military's resources are overwhelmingly devoted to patrolling and guarding the occupied West Bank, at the expense of the country's vulnerable southern communities. But it cannot be a coincidence that this operation was launched as Israel has been experiencing its worst civic conflict in years, with the government's campaign to ;overhaul the judiciary;—attempts that have been met with weekly mass demonstrations and public fury. Military reservists, who had been among the fiercest critics of the government's actions, today called on Israelis to unite and report for service. The leaders of the protest movement swiftly declared that tonight's planned protests—for the fortieth week—have been cancelled.

;

;But the story that is emerging as perhaps the most worrying of all is the murkiness of the hostage situation. There were unverified reports from Hamas that about thirty-five Israelis, soldiers and civilians, have been taken hostage. Again, this is unverified: one must assume that a misinformation campaign is under way. Still, Israel has not dealt with violence this grave since the second intifada, two decades ago; any country will be greatly tested under such circumstances. The spectre of hostages is especially grave. In 2011, an Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, was released after five years in Hamas captivity in exchange for more than a thousand prisoners, primarily Palestinians. Three years later, a ;controversial Israeli-military directive; on the prevention of hostage-taking received new scrutiny. It's still too early—and too devastating—to know the picture that will emerge from this coördinated attack. In Israel, there is already talk about this being the beginning of a protracted “Sukkot War.” ♦

;是否有一位政客受到广泛的鄙视，包括他自己的政客派对，却像马特·盖茨一样高效？这位佛罗里达州国会议员此前因坚定支持唐纳德·特朗普的选举否认主义以及因性贩运指控而接受调查（他否认了这些指控，司法部也拒绝提出指控）而闻名，他策划罢免了凯文·麦卡锡的议长职务上周，他在 221 名众议院共和党议员中得到了另外 7 名共和党议员的支持。麦卡锡的支持者谴责盖茨的派系是“拿着剪刀奔跑的混乱”特工。就连盖茨党内莫洛托夫主义的精神祖父纽特·金里奇（Newt Gingrich）后来也呼吁将他逐出共和党核心小组。从某种意义上说，盖茨正在做特朗普本月在法庭诉讼中一直在做的事情：测试;MAGA;运动是否可以简单地作为一场持续的叛乱来运作，反对其原则不关心的任何事物

;

;然而，在周二下午关于退出议长职位的长达一小时的决定性辩论中，盖茨也表现出了对政治弱点的敏锐洞察力。麦卡锡的支持者一波又一波地起来抗议，认为解雇一位在通过法案和监督方面取得如此进展的议长是不公平的。盖茨不停地问，“有什么进展吗？”盖茨说，麦卡锡派吹嘘的许多法案（其中一些提议大幅削减社会支出和放松拜登政府的能源政策）在民主党控制的参议院到达时就已经失效，“不是法律”。 “当众议院共和党人甚至没有向亨特·拜登发出传票时，很难支持监督，”他补充道。 “这看起来有点像失败剧场。”当众议院准备进行最后投票时，盖茨站在一群民主党人面前，他们对他持怀疑态度，但仍然会与他一起投票，他放下笔记并停止讲话，几乎完全没有朋友，但却是华盛顿的核心人物.

;

;此刻，麦卡锡派显得更加自然地同情。他们看上去真的很痛苦。投票结束后，当所有民主党人都加入八名叛乱分子的行列，结束麦卡锡议长的任期时，据报道，一些共和党人蜷缩在地板上祈祷。麦卡锡的盟友已经清楚地看到了盖茨的机会主义：路易斯安那州的加勒特·格雷夫斯(Garret Graves)表示，佛罗里达州国会议员的竞选团队利用他对麦卡锡的挑战，在盖茨在众议院发言时发送短信寻求捐款，即使按照国会的标准，这也是不可接受的。不可否认，很恶心。但麦卡锡的盟友为议长辩护的演讲对盖茨的激进分子来说太过分了。他们谴责拜登政府“无法无天”，并宣称麦卡锡的多数派是抵御“黑暗和可怕现实”的“唯一防火墙”。他们越是坚称国家形势危急，就越是为盖茨辩护。

;

;关于盖茨的叛乱，最重要的是，它已经发生了很长时间。哈佛大学政治学家西达·斯科波尔（Theda Skocpol）在接受 Politico 采访时指出，自乔治·W·布什政府执政以来，共和党草根阶层一直存在一种“自下而上的激进化”模式。保守派选民对移民和社会转型越来越愤怒，并对承诺扭转这些变化但未能实现的共和党政客感到不满。

;
;
;

;但是共和党的激进化进程缓慢至少同样取决于建制派对这些力量的投降。麦卡锡在党内的生存时间比保罗·瑞安或埃里克·坎托要长，因为他的承认更多。 1月6日后，他飞往海湖庄园欢迎特朗普重返党内；他与玛乔丽·泰勒·格林结盟；他下令对拜登总统进行大规模的弹劾调查，这正是基地所希望的。如果麦卡锡的政治交换理论奏效，并且这些为“MAGA”派系所做的恩惠得到了回报，那么党内唯一有能力拯救他的人可能会这么做。但上周，当一名记者在曼哈顿市中心法院询问特朗普是否支持麦卡锡时，这位前总统只是淡淡地置之不理。

;

;当然，现在特朗普也有自己的问题。他在法庭上为自己辩护，反对纽约总检察长利蒂西亚·詹姆斯对他、他的企业、他的两个大儿子以及特朗普集团其他高管提出的民事指控。该诉讼称，他们欺诈性地夸大了特朗普所持资产的价值，在该案中，他将损失两亿五千万美元，同时也失去了在纽约经营一家企业的权利，而这构成了他品牌的重要组成部分。 。到目前为止，审判对他来说进展并不顺利：他运气不好，请到了法官亚瑟·恩戈隆(Arthur Engoron)，后者对特朗普的辩护几乎没有耐心（“这太荒谬了，”法官在特朗普的一系列询问中抱怨道。前总统的一位律师），而谁将决定结果，部分原因是特朗普的律师莫名其妙地未能要求陪审团审判。即使在法庭案件的背景下，否认有任何不当行为的特朗普现在显然已经放弃了所有社会（更不用说后总统）规范，谴责审判是“腐败的”，恩戈隆是“流氓”，詹姆斯是“政治动物”，恩戈隆的法律助理是参议院多数党领袖查克·舒默的“女朋友”。

;;MAGA;运动通常被描述为极右派别，但其当前的化身，个人崇拜若隐若现大，政治上比这更阴暗一些。盖茨和他的七名叛乱分子中的大多数都与极端主义自由核心小组有联系。但他们也包括南卡罗来纳州的南希·梅斯，她是一位相对温和的人，她对麦卡锡的不满是麦卡锡违背了自己的承诺，她说，其中包括扩大节育机会的承诺。 （大多数自由核心小组支持麦卡锡。）如此多的共和党人对盖茨表达的愤怒表明，他们已经厌倦了一种“让外人永远是对的，而党从不做事”的逻辑。足够的。但麦卡锡的继任者可能会是一位更加保守的议长（路易斯安那州的史蒂夫·斯卡利斯和来自俄亥俄州的自由核心小组的护身符吉姆·乔丹都宣布参选，特朗普也支持乔丹）。在此过程中，该党只是温顺地争夺特朗普的候选资格，即使是在他的几次审判中。

;

;1989 年的某个时候，Terry Bisson 开车送女儿去纽约州北部上大学时，突然想到了一个短片的想法他想到了故事。他朝高速公路中间线看了一眼，看到了这样的景象：动物们坐在一起，在自己的世界里互相交谈。这个愿景变成了一个标题：“熊发现火。”

;

;由此产生的故事既奇怪又有趣，但又异常现实。故事发生在比森长大的肯塔基州，但故事发生在“无人认领的土地”上，这可以代替任何远郊荒野，讲述了叔叔和侄子经历的一个奇怪的季节，在这个季节里，熊停止冬眠并发现了火。 “他们生火并让整个冬天一直燃烧，”一个角色解释道。没有人知道如何看待这一发展。叔叔和他的侄子小华莱士在电视上关注这个故事，但感到沮丧的是，新闻主要显示的是“人们在谈论熊”，而不是熊本身。他们决定去寻找真品。

;

;晚饭后，他们走进后院，穿过栅栏。 “穿过州际公路，穿过树林，我们可以看到熊的火焰，”比森写道。 “小华莱士想回家拿他的 0.22 步枪去打一枪，我解释了为什么这样做是错误的。”此外，叔叔还指出，“0.22 对熊来说只会让它发疯。”后来，小华莱士脾气暴躁的奶奶逃离了疗养院，消失在黑暗的荒野中。他们发现她和熊在一起，静静地享受篝火。 “我的想象力非常丰富，”叔叔回忆道。 “我环顾四周，看着熊，想知道它们看到了什么。”

;

;“熊发现火”唤起了气候变化和自然的差异性。它捕捉到了我们对周围世界变化的快乐和好奇心。这并不完全是科幻小说。这更像是一个寓言。当比森写完这本书后，他把它寄给了;Asimov's;，这是科幻小说领域顶级杂志之一；编辑回信说，虽然这个故事不是科幻小说，但他还是想要它。 1990年和1991年，《熊发现火》几乎包揽了科幻和奇幻领域的所有奖项。

;然而，Bisson 已经很多年没有卖出过一个故事了。相反，从两千世纪初，或者也许是九十年代末——他已经记不清了——他一直在写可能是有史以来运行时间最长的每月小说专题。每个月，比森都会为湾区科幻贸易杂志《Locus》起草四个关于未来事件的简短段落。这些段落带有简短的标题（“教皇结婚”、“苹果收购雅诗兰黛”、“苏伊士运河关闭”），出现在“历史上的本月”标题下的小方框中，并且每个段落都与特定日期相关联（7 月 16 日，分别为 2049 年、2105 年 5 月 26 日和 2255 年 6 月 7 日）。科幻小说家 ;金·斯坦利·罗宾逊;是比森的老朋友，他告诉我，他将每个小插曲视为一部小说的开头，或者是整部小说的压缩版。他敦促我拿到整个档案，其中包含一千多个条目。我借用了;Locus;的一些旧刊：

;
;
;

;2099年3月22日。亚马逊收购了亚马逊。在批评家眼中的环境“万福玛丽”中，这家零售巨头为 Prime Preserve 购买了 800 万平方公里的碳汇，其中还包括新泽西州和苏丹的湿地。

;

;2114 年 2 月 11 日。垃圾气体”禁令。世界大会推翻了美国/以色列的联合否决，禁止民用使用 C-330，这种军事攻击性毒气会使人群失禁。

;

;2176 年 11 月 9 日。火星上的第一只狗。 Yeolhan 是现代殖民舰队的 94 架 Nureongi 中的一员，在着陆后不久通过厨房通风口逃脱，并在勇敢地试图吠叫时死亡，但具体原因从未被透露。

;

;在科幻小说中，什么才算合理或严肃？什么是愚蠢的——什么是古怪到令人相信的？您对这些问题的看法取决于您对未来的想法。我们生活在一个科幻盛行的时代，许多作家都追求严肃性，但严肃性可能是一种束缚，因为世界常常是荒谬的。 《历史上的这个月》来自一个更早、更宽松、更粗俗、更滑稽的科幻时代。这是该类型中流传时间最长的笑话，它提出了一种令人不安的可能性：如果低俗的荒谬是预测未来的好方法呢？

;

;出生于 1942 年的比森通过阅读他能读到的小说发现了科幻小说。药店里找。十三岁时，他读了詹姆斯·比利什（James Blish）的中篇小说《表面张力》（Surface Tension），讲述了人类通过基因改造后代以殖民新星球的故事。那时，他喜欢偷偷从父母那里拿烟，晚上沿着烟田散步时抽烟；他仰望星空，想起比利什的小说，“这里没有其他人知道它的存在。”后来，在六十年代，他发现了“垮掉的一代”，并搬到了纽约，希望出版他的第一部小说《钻石吉姆》。 JD Salinger 的经纪人接手了这本书，但未能出版。 “我以为我正徘徊在职业生涯的边缘，”比森回忆道。相反，他以洗碗和写封面文案为生。

;

;1969 年，比森放弃写作十年，离开纽约前往南部和西南部的“嬉皮公社”工作。他在一个公社遇到了他的妻子朱迪·詹森（Judy Jensen），他们加入了“5 月 19 日共产主义组织”（5 月 19 日共产主义组织），该组织是由前地下气象组织成员创建的。 1975 年，夫妇俩搬回纽约组织 5 月 19 日的活动，比森在出租车车库担任汽车修理工，并担任文案撰稿人。他卖出了他的第一本科幻小说“;Wylrdmaker;”，1981 年送给出版商 David Hartwell，售价 1500 美元。这部小说很通俗：它讲述了帕斯特林的科门的故事，这是野蛮人柯南的讽刺未来版本。这不是比森想写的书，他告诉我，但“这是我做过的最聪明的事情。就在那时我发现你不必非得是海明威或菲茨杰拉德才能写小说。”他的第二部小说“;会说话的人;”更像是一个充满激情的项目——这是一部以南方乡村为背景的奇幻小说，垃圾场而不是城堡。 “有一种感觉，科幻小说是一种非常城市化的文学，而未来则是一个非常城市化的地方，”作家凯伦·乔伊·福勒告诉我。 “特里的观点更加基于土地、区域性和民粹主义。”

;
;
;

;如果 5 月 19 日要求他这样做任何有风险的事情，比森都会做。但他一直被怀疑是“小资产阶级知识分子”，因而被边缘化。 1985年，他被传唤在大陪审团面前作证，以查明那些躲藏起来的朋友以及涉嫌制造国会大厦和附近三个军事基地爆炸案的朋友。他拒绝服从，并在监狱里度过了三个月——他指出，与他的朋友们相比，这段时间很短。在那里，比森开始了他的第三部小说，“;山上的火;”，废奴主义者约翰的另类历史布朗在哈珀斯费里的起义成功了。 1988 年该书出版时，比森将这本书献给了库瓦西·巴拉贡 (Kuwasi Balagoon) 和黑人解放军。

;

;比森作为一名小说家从来都不是很成功，但作为一名作家，他获得了很多工作。他以笔名创作非小说类小说和青少年小说，并为《约翰尼助记符》、《第五元素》和《异形复活》等电影撰写小说。他改编自;威廉·吉布森;、格雷格贝尔、;简·奥斯汀;、莎士比亚、罗杰·泽拉兹尼和安妮麦卡弗里进入漫画界。他为《消费者报告》撰写了文案，还为 NPR 的“Car Talk”撰写了一本介绍机械师的书。他编辑了政治犯的著作，最著名的是“;爱与奋斗;，”大卫·吉尔伯特的回忆录地下天气因抢劫和谋杀被减刑四十年。在此期间，他和 Jensen 经营着 Jacobin Books，这是一家为囚犯提供邮购图书服务的公司。

;
;
;

;1990 年，Bisson 四十八岁，当时《熊发现火》曾短暂出版他是一个明星。第二年，他在《Omni》上发表了他最著名的故事“它们是用肉做的”。这个故事本质上是两个发现人类存在的外星人之间的对话，是“有史以来最伟大的前数字模因之一”，作家乔纳森·莱瑟姆告诉我。 “它们是用肉做的，”一位外星人说。 “肉？”另一个人难以置信地回答道。 “这是毫无疑问的，”第一个说。 “我们从地球的不同地方挑选了几个，把它们带上我们的侦察船，对它们进行全程探测。它们完全是肉。”他们继续：

;“没有大脑？”

;

;“哦，有大脑好吧。只是大脑是肉做的！”

;

;“所以。 。 。你在想什么？”

;

;“你不明白，是吗？大脑负责思考。肉。”

;

;“会思考的肉！你让我相信肉思考！”

;

;“是的，肉思考！”有意识的肉！爱吃肉。梦见肉。肉就是一切！你明白了吗？”

;
;
;

;“它们是用肉做的”已被制作为广播剧，改编为两部电影，并由史蒂芬·平克引用，尼尔·德格拉斯·泰森和其他科学家提出了意识如何从物质中产生的哲学难题。 Bisson 从 ;Omni; 那里收到了一小笔报酬，但大部分收入都是通过 ESL 教科书的重印获得的。故事发生后，他的第五部小说《宇宙海盗》成为 1996 年评论最多的科幻小说，但他的收入最多来自在《花花公子》上发表故事。他与《花花公子》编辑爱丽丝·特纳 (Alice Turner) 以及其他人一起，在克格勃酒吧为知名作家和新晋作家创作并运营了著名的纽约市阅读系列。

;

;2002 年，又写了几本小说后，比森和詹森离开纽约前往旧金山。他在那里开始了一个阅读系列——科幻小说中的科幻小说——并开始撰写《历史上的这个月》。 2012 年，他出版了最后一本小说“;现在任何一天;，”最后几天的另类历史罗宾逊向我形容《垮掉的一代》是“六十年代伟大的小说”。除此之外，他完全专注于他未来的头条新闻。 “我问他还写了什么，”;Locus; 的主编 Liza Trombi 告诉我。 “他对我说，‘Ly-zuh’——你知道，用那种口音——‘你没明白吗？我受够了。' ”

;

;比森-詹森 (Bisson-Jensen) 的家位于奥克兰，是一栋小型郊区平房，前花园风景优美。比森穿着灰色牛仔裤和灰色格子衬衫来开门。如今，他已经八十多岁了，身材矮胖，腰短，腿长，就像一名骑师。我们之前在 2005 年通过电子邮件见过一次面。我请他为我正在编辑的一本书写一篇后记。我礼貌地写了一封“亲爱的比森先生”的信，他只用了一句话作为回应：“有面团吗？”他拄着拐杖走路，但用空着的那只手坚定地与我握手，并把我拉过来拥抱。

;

;在后花园，比森一边喝着菊苣咖啡，一边嚼着烟草，一边回忆着他的职业生涯。他清楚地记得每份工作的报酬。 （其中收入最高的是他为纳斯卡写的一系列儿童读物。）他回忆起写了一系列“星球大战”小说，主角是一个他从未听说过的角色，名叫波巴·费特。 “这种情况并没有持续多久，”他说。 “他们看得出来我根本不在乎《星球大战》。” ”

;

;我要求看看他在哪里工作，然后我们搬进了室内，经过手工制作的被子、不匹配的手绘瓷器和质朴的木制家具。 “我们称之为乡村嬉皮士，”比森说。壁炉架上方悬挂着一幅由他们的孙子奥申 (Ocean) 绘制的埃尔维斯 (Elvis) 解构肖像；国王被像素化得没有任何特征，但仍然清晰可见。比森坐在客厅阳光明媚的角落的沙发上。 “就是这样，”他说。他喜欢维多利亚时代的文学，有一摞关于奥斯曼的书，包括特罗洛普和奥斯汀。 （“2042 年 6 月 23 日，Janeite 狂欢节。好莱坞和藤街交通拥堵，估计有 1750 人静静地为好莱坞星光大道上的新星鼓掌。”）他删除了 Boswell 的一份破烂副本“;塞缪尔·约翰逊的一生;”。 （“2109 年 3 月 4 日，威拉·约翰逊去世。这位备受赞誉的学者被发现死在克拉里昂社区学院的小隔间里，她的研究证实《塞缪尔·约翰逊》是詹姆斯·博斯韦尔的虚构作品，颠覆了几个世纪的文学史。”）他说，他喜欢博斯韦尔，不仅仅是因为写作，还因为你可以从任何一页开始阅读。

;

;Jensen 的缝纫机在房子的另一个地方嗡嗡作响。维多利亚时代的小说旁边放着几本来自《直言不讳的作家》的薄卷，这是他为无政府主义出版商 PM Press 编辑的系列丛书。每卷都包含比森的采访。 （“曾经乘独木舟沿着戈瓦努斯运河航行过吗？”他问乔纳森·莱瑟姆。“我曾经去过。”）比森在自己的系列书中采访了自己。

;
;
;

;当比森发现科幻小说时，作家似乎只对基于太空的未来感兴趣。 “当我们离开这个星球时会发生什么——那就是狗屎真正开始发生的时候，”他回忆起那些日子说道。但他一直对地球上看似平凡的变化着迷。 “机器人和太空旅行远不如互联网、高速公路系统或空调那么有趣，”他说。他喜欢亚马逊，尽管他“不应该”。比森在他的网站上曾经引用过超现实主义者和共产主义者保罗·艾吕雅的话：“还有另一个世界，但它就在这个世界里。”当被问及这个问题时，他温和地说，“这就是我想要进入的世界。”

;

;在开车回家的路上，我想知道“历史上的这个月份”的未来。比森最近被诊断出患有结肠癌。他担心找不到合适的编剧来接手这部作品；他不希望它演变成“愚蠢的喜剧”。他将所有这些内容汇编成一本书，并将作为我在杜克大学出版社编辑的实践系列的一部分以“明天”为题出版。与此同时，他继续撰写专栏，每月十五日提交。他称之为他的日常工作。

;

;《历史上的这个月》中描绘的时间线既令人着迷又熟悉。我们可能会殖民火星，或者亚马逊可能会收购亚马逊，但我们必须学会将这些事件吸收到我们的日常生活中，但我们仍将保持我们的日常生活。正如《熊发现火》中的叔叔想知道熊会看到什么一样，比森不仅想知道未来会带来什么，还想知道我们将如何看待它。灾难即将来临，就像它们总是来一样，但是，在他的世界里，我们不是作为拯救世界的英雄来对待它们，而是作为慷慨的观察者，对可能性和遭遇持开放态度。当我们搞砸时——我们确实会搞砸——我们应该有耐心，并自嘲一笑。我们甚至可能值得宽恕。我的意思是，看看我们。我们是肉做的。 ♦
